intro: Cinchona scrobiculata var. genuina, commonly known as the Andean quinine tree, is a species native to the Andes Mountains of South America. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and clusters of small, white flowers. The plant produces red, fleshy berries that contain seeds, and it thrives in high-altitude, humid environments. It is known for its historical use in the production of quinine, a compound used to treat malaria. Its botanical features make it an important species in both ecological and medicinal contexts.
